behavioral_systems_issues.title: Implement PennMUSH Queue Behavior: Priority, Chunking, and WAIT/INDEPENDENT Separation
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

SharpMUSH has a working task scheduler but is missing key PennMUSH queue behaviors that affect performance and compatibility.

## Missing Features

1. **Queue Priority System** - Different priorities for player vs object vs system commands
2. **Queue Chunking** - `queue_chunk` config: how many commands run before checking sockets
3. **WAIT vs INDEPENDENT Queues** - Distinction between queue types
4. **Queue Entry Limits** - Max entries per object/player
5. **Queue Cost/Quota** - Queue entries should cost quota
6. **Break Propagation** - Proper handling of @break across queue contexts
7. **SETQ in Queued Context** - Q-register behavior in queued vs immediate execution

## Implementation Notes

- TaskQueueType enum exists but not fully utilized (TaskScheduler.cs:48-68)
- Queue infrastructure is solid, needs behavioral layers
- See PennMUSH documentation reference in penntop.md about queue_chunk

## Testing Requirements

- Benchmark queue processing performance
- Test queue priority ordering
- Verify quota costs are applied
- Test SETQ behavior in queued vs immediate context
- Test @break propagation through queues

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/TaskScheduler.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/Interfaces/ITaskScheduler.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/InformationFunctions.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Commands/GeneralCommands.cs

## Estimated Effort

40-60 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Queue priority system implemented and working
- [ ] queue_chunk configuration option added and functional
- [ ] WAIT and INDEPENDENT queues separated
- [ ] Queue limits enforced per object/player
- [ ] Queue operations cost quota appropriately
- [ ] @break propagation works correctly
- [ ] SETQ behavior matches PennMUSH in all contexts
- [ ] Comprehensive tests added
- [ ] Performance benchmarks show no regression

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Implement Zone System Infrastructure
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

Zones are a cross-cutting PennMUSH feature affecting permissions, inheritance, emission, matching, and locks. Currently 19 TODOs reference zone functionality.

## Missing Features

1. **Zone Master Controls** - Zone masters controlling objects in their zone
2. **Zone Inheritance** - Attribute inheritance from zones
3. **Zone Emission** - @zemit, @nszemit commands
4. **Zone Object Retrieval** - zone() function returning correct zone
5. **Zone Matching** - Match functions checking zone visibility
6. **Zone Lock Evaluation** - Lock inheritance and evaluation through zones

## Architecture Requirements

```
1. Zone parent tracking in database
2. Zone attribute inheritance walker
3. Zone permission checking service
4. Zone-based locate/match algorithms
5. Zone emission notification system
6. Zone lock evaluation integration
```

## Implementation Notes

- Affects PermissionService, LocateService, AttributeService, LockService
- 19 TODOs across multiple files
- Cross-cutting concern requiring phased implementation

## Testing Requirements

- Test zone master permissions
- Test attribute inheritance from zones
- Test zone emission to all zone members
- Test zone() function accuracy
- Test zone-based matching and locating
- Test zone lock inheritance

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/PermissionService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/LocateService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/AttributeService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/DbrefFunctions.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/AttributeFunctions.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/ConnectionFunctions.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/CommunicationFunctions.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Commands/GeneralCommands.cs

## Estimated Effort

80-120 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Zone master permissions fully functional
- [ ] Zone attribute inheritance working
- [ ] Zone emission commands working (@zemit, @nszemit)
- [ ] zone() function returns correct zone
- [ ] Zone-based matching integrated
- [ ] Zone locks evaluated correctly
- [ ] All 19 zone TODOs resolved
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage
- [ ] Documentation updated

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Fix CommandDiscoveryService Performance Issue (SEVERE)
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

**SEVERITY: CRITICAL PERFORMANCE ISSUE**

CommandDiscoveryService currently scans all attributes on every command match, causing O(n) performance degradation that scales with database size.

## Problem

```
Location: CommandDiscoveryService.cs:37
Current Behavior:
- Scans every attribute on every object for $command matches
- Performs conversions repeatedly
- No caching mechanism
- Performance degrades linearly with database size
```

## Required Solution

1. Build command index at startup
2. Cache compiled $command patterns
3. Invalidate cache only when $commands change
4. Use hash-based lookup instead of full scan
5. Implement incremental index updates

## Performance Impact

- **Current**: O(n) where n = total attributes in database
- **Target**: O(1) hash lookup with cache
- **Expected Improvement**: 100-1000x speedup depending on database size

## Implementation Approach

```csharp
1. Create CommandIndex service
2. Scan and index $commands at startup
3. Monitor attribute changes for $commands
4. Invalidate and rebuild index entries on change
5. Use hash map for O(1) lookups
```

## Testing Requirements

- Benchmark before/after with various database sizes
- Test cache invalidation on attribute changes
- Test concurrent access to command index
- Verify correctness of pattern matching
- Memory usage profiling

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/Interfaces/ICommandDiscoveryService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Services/CommandDiscoveryService.cs (assumed)

## Estimated Effort

40-60 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Command discovery uses indexed lookup
- [ ] Performance improved by >100x for large databases
- [ ] Cache invalidation working correctly
- [ ] Memory usage acceptable
- [ ] All existing $command patterns still work
- [ ] Comprehensive benchmarks showing improvement
- [ ] Unit tests for edge cases
- [ ] Documentation updated

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Implement Attribute Pattern Modes and Fix Parent Chain Walking
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

Attribute pattern matching and parent chain walking are incomplete, affecting attribute operations like @set obj/attr* and inheritance.

## Missing Features

1. **Pattern Mode Support** - Attribute patterns like obj/attr* don't work correctly
2. **Tree Traversal** - Hierarchical attributes (obj/parent`child) broken
3. **Parent Chain Walking** - Attribute inheritance doesn't follow proper hierarchy
4. **Wildcard Operations** - Bulk operations on attr* patterns unreliable

## TODO Locations

- AttributeService.cs:354, 371 - "// TODO: Implement Pattern Modes"
- AttributeService.cs (3 instances) - "// TODO: This code doesn't quite look right. It does not correctly walk the parent chain."
- ArangoDatabase.cs (2 instances) - "// TODO: This is a lazy implementation and does not appropriately support the ` section of pattern matching for attribute trees."
- UtilityFunctions.cs - Tree structure handling marked as incorrect

## PennMUSH Expected Behavior

```
obj/attr - Direct attribute
obj/parent`child - Hierarchical attribute
obj/attr* - Wildcard match (all attributes starting with 'attr')
Inherit from parent objects
Inherit from zones
Pattern-based bulk operations
```

## Implementation Notes

- AttributeService has infrastructure but incomplete implementation
- Database layer needs tree traversal support
- Parent chain walking affects permission checks and attribute lookups

## Testing Requirements

- Test direct attribute access (obj/attr)
- Test hierarchical attributes (obj/parent`child)
- Test wildcard patterns (obj/attr*)
- Test parent object inheritance
- Test zone inheritance integration
- Test bulk operations on patterns
- Test edge cases (circular parents, missing attributes, etc.)

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/AttributeService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/Interfaces/IAttributeService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Database.ArangoDB/ArangoDatabase.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/UtilityFunctions.cs

## Estimated Effort

60-80 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Pattern modes fully implemented
- [ ] Parent chain walking correct
- [ ] Tree traversal supports ` notation
- [ ] Wildcard patterns work correctly
- [ ] Attribute inheritance from parents works
- [ ] Zone attribute inheritance works (after zone system)
- [ ] All attribute TODOs resolved
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage
- [ ] Performance acceptable for large attribute sets

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Implement Hook System (Replace Placeholder)
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

IHookService interface exists and is well-designed, but implementation is a placeholder. Command hooks (@hook) don't actually modify behavior.

## Hook System Features

```csharp
Hook Types: ignore, override, before, after, extend
Hook Options:
- Inline execution
- Q-register control (localize, clearregs)
- Break propagation control (nobreak)
- Per-command hooks
```

## Current Status

```
Location: HookService.cs:77
Status: "// TODO: Replace placeholder implementation"
Interface: Complete and well-designed
Implementation: Placeholder methods returning defaults
```

## Implementation Requirements

1. Hook storage mechanism (database or memory)
2. Hook retrieval and caching
3. Hook execution in command pipeline
4. Q-register management (localize, clearregs)
5. Break propagation handling
6. Inline vs queued execution

## Testing Requirements

- Test all hook types (ignore, override, before, after, extend)
- Test inline execution
- Test Q-register localization
- Test Q-register clearing
- Test break propagation
- Test hook precedence
- Test hook removal
- Test multiple hooks on same command

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/Interfaces/IHookService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/HookService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Models/CommandHook.cs

## Estimated Effort

40-60 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All hook types functional (ignore, override, before, after, extend)
- [ ] Hook storage and retrieval working
- [ ] Inline execution working
- [ ] Q-register management correct
- [ ] Break propagation correct
- [ ] Hook caching for performance
- [ ] @hook command fully functional
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage
- [ ] Documentation updated

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Complete Move Service Implementation
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

IMoveService interface exists but only defines loop checking. Full move mechanics are incomplete, affecting commands like GET, DROP, ENTER, LEAVE.

## Current Implementation

```csharp
IMoveService.cs defines:
- WouldCreateLoop(objectToMove, destination): Circular containment check
```

## Missing Move Features

1. Enter/Leave attribute triggering (@ENTER, @LEAVE, @OXENTER, @OXLEAVE)
2. Move cost checking
3. Permission validation (can_move, move_lock)
4. Location updates in database
5. Contents notification
6. Room verb triggering (@OTELEPORT, @OXTELEPORT, etc.)
7. Move failure messages
8. Recursive move handling (moving containers with contents)

## Related TODOs

```
Location: GeneralCommands.cs
Current: "// TODO: Evaluate room verbs upon teleportation."
Impact: Teleport commands don't fire appropriate hooks
```

## Implementation Requirements

1. Complete MoveService implementation
2. Integrate with AttributeService for hook firing
3. Integrate with PermissionService for checks
4. Database location updates
5. Notification system for contents
6. Cost calculation and quota deduction

## Testing Requirements

- Test simple moves (GET, DROP)
- Test enter/leave hooks
- Test permission checks
- Test move costs
- Test circular containment prevention
- Test recursive moves
- Test teleportation verbs
- Test move failure cases
- Test notification to affected players

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/Interfaces/IMoveService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Commands/GeneralCommands.cs (GET, DROP, ENTER, LEAVE)
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/AttributeService.cs (for hook firing)

## Estimated Effort

50-70 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Full MoveService implementation
- [ ] Enter/Leave hooks fire correctly
- [ ] Move costs calculated and applied
- [ ] Permission checks working
- [ ] Location updates in database
- [ ] Contents notifications working
- [ ] Teleport verbs fire correctly
- [ ] Circular containment prevented
- [ ] All move-related commands working
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage
- [ ] Documentation updated

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Implement 15 Utility Function Stubs
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

15+ utility functions are defined but not implemented in UtilityFunctions.cs. These are commonly-used softcode functions that limit builder capabilities.

## Unimplemented Functions

1. **grep()** - Pattern search across attributes
2. **clone()** - Object cloning
3. **dig()** - Room creation
4. **link()** - Object linking
5. **open()** - Exit creation
6. **render()** - Code evaluation from another object's perspective
7. **scan()** - Attribute scanning
8. **tel()** - Teleportation
9. **testlock()** - Lock testing
10. **Plus 5-6 more** utility functions

## TODO Status

```
Location: UtilityFunctions.cs
TODOs: 21 total, 15 marked as major implementations
Impact: Builders cannot use these common functions
```

## Implementation Notes

- Interfaces likely already defined
- Need to integrate with existing services:
  - grep() needs AttributeService
  - clone() needs ManipulateSharpObjectService
  - dig()/open() need building services
  - render() needs parser with different perspective
  - testlock() needs LockService
  - tel() needs MoveService

## Testing Requirements

**For Each Function:**
- Test with valid inputs
- Test with invalid inputs
- Test permission checks
- Test edge cases
- Test with unique test strings (e.g., "test_string_GREP_case1")
- Compare behavior to PennMUSH

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/UtilityFunctions.cs
- Various service interfaces for integration

## Estimated Effort

60-90 hours (4-6 hours per function average)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] grep() implemented and tested
- [ ] clone() implemented and tested
- [ ] dig() implemented and tested
- [ ] link() implemented and tested
- [ ] open() implemented and tested
- [ ] render() implemented and tested
- [ ] scan() implemented and tested
- [ ] tel() implemented and tested
- [ ] testlock() implemented and tested
- [ ] Remaining 5-6 functions implemented
- [ ] All functions have comprehensive tests
- [ ] Unique test strings used in tests
- [ ] PennMUSH compatibility verified
- [ ] Documentation updated

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Complete Permission Service: Attribute-Based Controls
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

PermissionService works for basic checks but is missing attribute-based permission controls, a key PennMUSH feature.

## Missing Features

1. **Attribute-Based Permission Controls** - Dynamic permissions via attributes
2. **Flag Restrictions** - Proper enforcement based on ownership/permissions
3. **Zone Master Permissions** - Integration with zone system

## TODO Locations

```
PermissionService.cs:37 - "// TODO: Implement attribute-based permission controls"
ManipulateSharpObjectService.cs - "// TODO: Flag Restrictions based on ownership, permissions, etc."
```

## Implementation Requirements

1. Attribute evaluation for permission checks
2. Caching of attribute-based permissions
3. Integration with AttributeService
4. Flag setting restrictions
5. Zone master permission checking (after zone system)

## Testing Requirements

- Test attribute-based permission grants
- Test attribute-based permission denials
- Test permission caching
- Test flag setting restrictions
- Test ownership-based restrictions
- Test zone master permissions (after zone system)

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/PermissionService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/Interfaces/IPermissionService.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/ManipulateSharpObjectService.cs

## Estimated Effort

30-40 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Attribute-based permissions implemented
- [ ] Permission caching working
- [ ] Flag restrictions enforced
- [ ] Zone master permissions integrated
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage
- [ ] Performance acceptable
- [ ] Documentation updated

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Fix mapsql() Safety Issue (DANGER)
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

**SEVERITY: CRITICAL - DANGER**

The mapsql() function has a known transformation bug that could lead to data corruption or security vulnerabilities.

## Problem

```
Location: SQLFunctions.cs:138
Priority: CRITICAL - DANGER
Current: "// TODO: mapsql() transformation bug"
Type: Functionality/Security bug
Impact: SQL operations may be unsafe or incorrect
```

## Required Investigation

1. Identify exact nature of transformation bug
2. Determine if it's a correctness or security issue
3. Review all SQL function implementations
4. Check for SQL injection vulnerabilities
5. Review parameter sanitization

## Testing Requirements

- Test mapsql() with various inputs
- Test for SQL injection attempts
- Test transformation correctness
- Test edge cases (special characters, etc.)
- Security audit of SQL functions

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/SQLFunctions.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/Interfaces/ISqlService.cs

## Estimated Effort

20-40 hours (depends on bug severity)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Bug identified and documented
- [ ] Fix implemented
- [ ] Security audit completed
- [ ] SQL injection tests pass
- [ ] Transformation correctness verified
- [ ] All SQL functions reviewed
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage
- [ ] Security documentation updated

3. **Lock Service Completion** - Whatever is marked incomplete at line 120

behavioral_systems_issues.title: Complete PID Tracking and Information Retrieval
behavioral_systems_issues.description:
## Overview

PID generation and tracking exist in TaskScheduler, but information retrieval functions (pid(), ps()) are incomplete.

## Current Status

✅ PID generation (TaskScheduler.cs:38-39)
✅ PID tracking for queued jobs
✅ PID-based semaphore queries

## Missing Features

```
TODO Location: InformationFunctions.cs
Current: "// TODO: Implement actual PID tracking and information retrieval"
Impact: pid() and ps() functions don't return full information
```

## Required Information

pid() should return:
- Process ID
- Object executing
- Command being executed
- Queue type (WAIT, INDEPENDENT, etc.)
- Time queued
- Time to execute

ps() should return:
- All queued processes for an object
- Process details
- Queue statistics

## Testing Requirements

- Test pid() accuracy
- Test ps() completeness
- Test process tracking across queue types
- Test process information updates

## Related Files

- SharpMUSH.Implementation/Functions/InformationFunctions.cs
- SharpMUSH.Library/Services/TaskScheduler.cs

## Estimated Effort

20-30 hours

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] pid() returns complete information
- [ ] ps() returns all processes
- [ ] Queue type information accurate
- [ ] Time information accurate
- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage
- [ ] Documentation updated
